image.altText: The 'big four'

items.synopsis: Australia's under-pressure banks unveil a new tool to combat fraudulent transactions, in a bid to stop customers losing more and more money to sophisticated scams.

title.children: Banks launch new weapon to help recover scam victims' money

image.altText: A police car blocks a road in front of a fire.

items.synopsis: Multiple people have died after a fire broke out overnight at a four-storey hostel in New Zealand's capital, Wellington, authorities have confirmed.

title.children: Fire crews face 'worst nightmare' as multiple people killed in New Zealand hostel blaze

image.altText: A large humpback whale swims alongside a calf just below the surface of the water at Ningaloo

items.synopsis: Ningaloo's sparkling turquoise waters and marine life are well known to many, but this World Heritage treasure extends to the land, too — and conservationists fear its future is on a knife's edge.

title.children: You might know it as an ocean paradise, but its magic unfolds on land too. Welcome to Ningaloo

image.altText: Richard Boyle

items.synopsis: It's a crisis that calls into question the wisdom of government outsourcing crucial functions and highlights the often cosy relationship between government, bureaucracy, regulators and the corporate world, writes Ian Verrender.

title.children: Richard Boyle faces life behind bars while those in the PwC scandal are protected by the corporate world

image.altText: A composite image of three women. One of the women holds a baby.

items.synopsis: Hopes, dreams, and disappointment. Five women aged between 24 and 41 share their stories of egg freezing.

title.children: Dreams and disappointments: Women share their stories of egg freezing

image.altText: A Red Rooster store and a Cold Rock store

items.synopsis: Two Victorian fast-food businesses are hit with hundreds of charges for allegedly failing to comply with child labour laws, as the state's watchdog cracks down on hospitality and retail franchises.

title.children: Two fast food businesses hit with hundreds of charges for allegedly failing to comply with child labour laws

image.altText: A male singer in a camo jacket sings on stage, grabbing a microphone. He wears sunglasses and gloves.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Vice Media files for bankruptcy, and The Weeknd is back to his birth name. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: More now on that deadly hostel fire in New Zealand's capital Wellington, which authorities say has killed at least six people. Wellington City Council spokesperson Richard MacLean tells ABC News Breakfast that a number of elderly people have been caught up in the emergency, as the hostel accommodates "a cross-section of the community". "The reason I say that is because the city council, we're opening a welfare centre this morning and we've got 50 people there who escaped the fire and a lot of them are elderly people," he says. "Everyone is absolutely traumatised by this event. This is not something that we normally expect to happen in Wellington. "I was just at the emergency centre we've set up. There's a lot of people there who just escaped pretty much in their pyjamas and bare feet into a very cold night. "We're basically having to go and find clothing for a whole bunch of people who have potentially lost everything."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wellington 'absolutely traumatised' after deadly hostel fire

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
More now on that deadly hostel fire in New Zealand's capital Wellington, which authorities say
has killed at least six people

Wellington City Council spokesperson Richard MacLean tells ABC News Breakfast that a number of elderly people have been caught up in the emergency, as the hostel accommodates "a cross-section of the community".

props.alt: A middle-aged man sits in a kitchen and speaks to a laptop during a TV interview

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
"The reason I say that is because the city council, we're opening a welfare centre this morning and we've got 50 people there who escaped the fire and a lot of them are elderly people," he says.
"Everyone is absolutely traumatised by this event. This is not something that we normally expect to happen in Wellington.
"I was just at the emergency centre we've set up. There's a lot of people there who just escaped pretty much in their pyjamas and bare feet into a very cold night.
"We're basically having to go and find clothing for a whole bunch of people who have potentially lost everything."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Authorities in New Zealand say multiple people have died after a fire broke out overnight at a four-storey hostel in the capital, Wellington. The Loafers Lodge hostel has a capacity for 92 guests, but it's unclear how many people were inside at the time of the fire, at around 12:30am local time. Police say their initial assessment "is that the number of deceased is fewer than 10". They say they are waiting to access and assess the building to confirm details. "It is currently unsafe and until we can access the building — and reconcile numbers of people who are safe — we are not in a position to determine how many people are deceased or unaccounted for," police say. "Our focus is on identifying those people as soon as we can."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Multiple fatalities after hostel fire in New Zealand

props.alt: Policeman being interview on New Zealand street

children.content: (ABC News)
Authorities in New Zealand say
multiple people have died after a fire broke out overnight at a four-storey hostel
in the capital, Wellington.
The Loafers Lodge hostel has a capacity for 92 guests, but it's unclear how many people were inside at the time of the fire, at around 12:30am local time.
Police say their initial assessment "is that the number of deceased is fewer than 10".
They say they are waiting to access and assess the building to confirm details.

"It is currently unsafe and until we can access the building — and reconcile numbers of people who are safe — we are not in a position to determine how many people are deceased or unaccounted for," police say.
"Our focus is on identifying those people as soon as we can."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: France will no longer host the Rugby League World Cup in 2025, with organisers citing a failure to meet financial criteria outlined by the French government. France won the bid to host the 2025 World Cup in January 2022. "Despite all the work carried out by the organising committee, it hasn't been possible to fully secure the risk of a deficit," organisers say. "Despite the interest shown in this unique sport … the board had to decide to renounce organizing this major international competition, which the International Rugby League had entrusted to France. "The conditions of financial viability initially defined by the state to support the project, set in January 2022, were not fully met, despite the search for solutions and the additional three months granted by the state to the organizing committee at the end of 2022." In a statement, International Rugby League (IRL) says it expects to be able to inform member nations of planned qualifying matches and alternative fixtures by July. France will host this year's men's rugby union World Cup from September 8 to October 28.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: France will no longer host the 2025 Rugby League World Cup

props.alt: A male rugby league player gestures to himself while wearing a France jersey during a game

children.content: (Reuters: Action Images/Ed Sykes)
France will no longer host the Rugby League World Cup in 2025, with organisers citing a failure to meet financial criteria outlined by the French government.
France won the bid to host the 2025 World Cup in January 2022.
"Despite all the work carried out by the organising committee, it hasn't been possible to fully secure the risk of a deficit," organisers say.
"Despite the interest shown in this unique sport … the board had to decide to renounce organizing this major international competition, which the International Rugby League had entrusted to France.

"The conditions of financial viability initially defined by the state to support the project, set in January 2022, were not fully met, despite the search for solutions and the additional three months granted by the state to the organizing committee at the end of 2022."
In a statement, International Rugby League (IRL) says it expects to be able to inform member nations of planned qualifying matches and alternative fixtures by July.
France will host this year's men's rugby union World Cup from September 8 to October 28.

image.altText: A woman sitting at a table looking serious.

items.synopsis: Home owner Katy says she's been struggling to meet her loan demands, and fears losing her home. What are the steps between missing a payment and losing your property?

image.altText: A man with fair hair and skin, wearing a suit jacket and an open-necked shirt.

image.altText: Donald Trump in blue suit and red tie speaking at podium with US flag in the background.

image.altText: Dr Janin Bredehoeft 1

image.altText: Man wearing a suit, standing next to a window.

image.altText: A black and white image of a dam that has been blown apart.

image.altText: Deaclan Crowley standing outside Foodbank.

items.synopsis: Many Australians rely on cheaper food to get by, and new data shows an increase in people are accessing help from food charities for the first time.

title.children: Food rescues and dumpster dives: How Australians facing food insecurity are feeding themselves

image.altText: Thailand elections

items.synopsis: Thailand's two main opposition parties agree to form a ruling coalition after they trounced in a weekend of election military-backed rivals that have controlled government for nearly a decade.

image.altText: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan, accompanied by his wife Ermine Erdogan, greets supporters.

items.synopsis: The head of Türkiye's High Election Board (YSK) confirms the presidential election will go to a run-off between President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and his main rival on May 28 as neither can reach the 50 per cent threshold to win outright.

image.altText: Man with greying beard wearing a beanie and hoodie, with serious expression, looks at camera

items.synopsis: Many veterans need help adjusting when they return home. But for Tasmanians, that often means spending weeks interstate getting treatment.

image.altText: a man examining a large orange fossil, bigger than his head

image.altText: Elisa Akpa sings the French national anthem before a Women's Rugby League World Cup game against Australia.

items.synopsis: French Rugby League World Cup organisers pull out of hosting the 2025 World Cup, saying financial pressures from the country's government are too great.

image.altText: A futuristic building surrounded by trees and landscaped gardens.

items.synopsis: It was supposed to be a "globally significant" cultural institution, but five years after an Aboriginal art gallery was first promised, the project remains on hold.

title.children: Five years on, Adelaide's Tarrkarri project remains a hole in the ground

image.altText: Black and white photo of man with fuzzy black hair and a jumper.

items.synopsis: The British post-punk band has many dedicated older female fans, but their fandom is not about fancying lead singer Robert Smith. It's much more interesting.

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin leaves a cemetery. He is bald and stares at the camera from a distance.

items.synopsis: Yevgeny Prigozhin offered to reveal the position of Russian troops to the Ukrainian government, the Washington Post reports, citing leaked US intelligence documents.

title.children: Wagner head reportedly offered to reveal Russian troop locations to Ukraine

image.altText: A collection of Chiang Kai-shek statues lumped together in a park

items.synopsis: Taiwan is littered with monuments to one of its most divisive leaders. However, as efforts to remove them stall, some activists to are taking matters into their own hands.

title.children: The spookiest park in Taiwan is an accidental monument to its divisive former dictator

image.altText: A man smiles with two others while posing for a selfie on stage in front of a large crowd.

items.synopsis: Thai voters have rejected the junta and its successors, instead looking set to vote in Thailand's most progressive party, Move Forward. But the election doesn't guarantee Thailand's opposition forces will be able to form government, writes Gregory Raymond.

image.altText: Jasmina, woman in pink shirt smiling, holding a baby wearing a blue shirt.

image.altText: A composite of images of a young and old Mick Doleman and a shipwreck under the ocean.

items.synopsis: The wreck of the Blythe Star is located almost 50 years after it sank off the Tasmanian coast, its crew believed dead — until, astonishingly, they appeared out of the bush far from where the ship sank.

image.altText: Sam Kerr squats behind the Women's FA Cup while holding the Australian flag and wearing her Chelsea jersey.
